item.title: Your First Leiningen REPL
item.description:
Before We Begin

Have you installed Leiningen? It is a requirement of running the lein repl! If you have no idea what I am saying you can head on over to the Setting Up Leiningen post

Your First lein REPL

I like to think of the read-eval-print loop (REPL) as the interactive programming mode of a language. The first time you create a REPL through lein, it will download any extra files it needs.

Open up one now in your terminal window with:

lein repl

You will now see that you have a new prompt that looks like:

user=>

You are now ready to get your Clojure on! When starting a new language, it is good luck to do the typical “Hello World”. To do this, we will use the println function.

Type the following Clojure command to bring yourself lots of good luck with Clojure:

(println "Hello World")

To leave the REPL, you just need to use CTRL + D

item.title: Setting Up Leiningen
item.description:
Before We Begin

This guide will be for setting up your environment in a Linux OS, I’m currently using Ubuntu. You will need Java version 1.6 or later, which is recommended by everything that I have read so far.

To check your Java version just open up a terminal and type:

java -version

To quote their website; Leiningen is “for automating Clojure projects without setting your hair on fire.” Leiningen will be helping us get Clojure running as well as manage any dependencies we use. Instructions are on their website for installing Leiningen, but they are not detailed enough for my liking, so I have made very thorough instructions.

Install Leiningen

Step 1. Open a terminal and download the lein script

Download the script right from the source listed on the Leiningen website

wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/technomancy/leiningen/stable/bin/lein

Step 2. Change ownership

Use chmod to change the ownership of the lein bash file you just downloaded to allow for anyone to execute the file.

chmod a+x lein

Step 3. Move lein

Now move lein–with super user privileges–to your system’s executable path.

sudo mv lein /usr/bin

If you are prompted to enter your password, do so and carry on.

Step 4. Run it

Now you will simply run lein and it will download the self-install package. If you try to run lein without super user privileges, it might yell at you about firewall junk. Be sure to press ENTER when it asks you to confirm this action.

sudo lein

Step 5. Confirm all is well

Just to make sure everything is good, let’s check the version of lein.

lein -v

You should receive an output similar to mine below (depending on your Java version).

> Leiningen 2.7.0 on Java 1.7.0_80 Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM

Next Steps

Now that you have Leiningen installed and the Clojure compiler downloaded, why don’t you start your first Leiningen REPL?
